REPORT OF THE AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS ■this department, we take pleasure in submitting to you our ind biennial report. I The following statements were compiled with great care from records of this office. We believe that a careful study of the liar statements will serve to give the public a clear under- itanding of all fiscal transactions of our state government I At the close of the last biennium. November .Sit. 1906, the iting interest-bearing debt of the state amounted to 11,916, - .31. At the close of the biennium. on November 30, .same amounted to $768,478.72, showing a decrease of $1.14v - ..59 for the period. The special levy provided by the Sheldon lias retired 1636,123.98 of the debt, and the balance of the or $512.(HJS.O4. arose from increased valuations and • property listed. This has been brought about by the opera - i of the new revenue law. A large majority of the county isurers report that under the present system over 99 pa the tax levied is collected. Statement No. 4 shows the total estimated income of the General Fund for the fiscal period commencing April 1. 1909, and ending March M. 1911, to be 14,389,92844. This estimate ■ed on 96* , of the probable levies of 1909 '10, assuming that the assessments and levies for t: is will not differ materi - ally from the total assessments and levies for the year 1908. This estimate, being based so nearly on a 100' , basis, necessitate BT (IK OF N KHUASKA. Ornci of Auditob <>k Public Accouk Lincoln, De< kmhkk 1. litov r<> His Kxrellencv. George Lawson Sheldon. Governor of the State of Nebraska: Dcai Sik: — In comptiance with statutes relative to reports

6 Inate on that The reports heretofore have been i have done away with that basis, owing to the ■isions made under the new revenue law for the collection of total amount levied, although So' , was a good average under old law. I The total assessed value of all property in the state for the 1906 was 001,785,464.08, and the levy for Ceneral Fund om was 4\ mills. The results of the working of the new iue law are more gratifying each year; we find more equitable isments and more property returned for assessment each year. To the estimated income from levies of 1909-lOhaa been added Miniate of the income from back taxes and ilaneous sou shown in statement No. 4. Against the estimated Gemral Fund of $4,389,928.64 are ■1 the estimated requirements for the biennial period com - mencing April 1. I'M), amounting to 15,191,436.09, chargeable to the (ieneral Fund and set forth in Statement No. 5. Estil ■tail have l>een prepared by the heads of departments and institutions and are on file in this department. I As usual, the estimated expenses for the next biennium ed the estimated receipts; in this instance by $701,497.4") ill l>e necessary for the legislature to carry on the good busi - adniinistration we have heretofore had. and keep tht litures within the provisions of the law. The past four \< rience has demonstrated the wisdom of the new revenue law. under its workings the State has been put on a sound financial : . The old indebtedness has practically l>een paid off. and •xpenditures kept within the receipts, all without excessive and ensome levies to provide for the needs of our growing Bi I Thanks to the Sheldon Act. passed by the efforts of the prc rnor when he was a nieml)er of the state Senate, the floating l>tedness will l>e cleaned up by .July 1. 190(1. when our I be reduced another mill. This, with the reduction of the levy, will make our state taxes very light. I A summary of the Insurance business of the state for the nium is incorporated herein and made a part of this report. John L. Pierce, insurance deputy, in his letter of transmittal. ishes a statement of the receipts incident to the department ng the biennium. In connection with the Insurance Depart - t. I wish to especially call your attention to the growth evi-

7 denced by the increased receipts. The receipts for the l>ienniuni of 4M amounted to $212,196.07, and for 1907-08 to 1223,74 an increase of 111,544.87. An examination of the report of miscel - us receipts of the different offices will show that this depart - ment collects about 70' , of all fees paid into the State Treasury. 1 also wish to mention the special appropriations. su> the one for the use of the State Entomologist. Insect pcatl and plant diseases, and Geological Survey. These appropriations are placed in absolute control of one man. but should I in the hands of the state university, that some state officer may proper supervision over the expenditure of the funds. It is impossible for this Department to know what work is l>eing done under these special appropriations, and as the men wh pend these funds are appointed by the state Hoard of Regents, the money should also be expended under the supervision of the Repents. This rule should apply to all special appropriations. In view of the much increased and exacting duties devolv - ing on the secretary of the State Hoard of Equalization t As - icnt by the enactment of the terminal tax law. which, by its nature, calls for a high degree of ability and experience in the ii of its secretary, and which with the other work of his office now demands his entire and undivided time and attention. I would earnestly recommend that the Legislature l>e aske to increase his salary from $16(M) to $2000 per annum; also that the lature provide for the making and publication by him annual report, similar to such reports in other states, makil appropriation therefor. Respectfully submitted. K. M. Seakle, Jr.. Auditor of Public Accounts.

419 LEGISLATION AND RECOMMENDATIONS. At the session of the Legislature of l>(07 there was recommended b] Department the passage of most of the Laws which hail been drawn by the < i iMMITTEE OF FIFTEEN* in l'.toti: bui as the question of Insurance « in the party platform of the Republican 1'arty and as the reform nieasu that platform Wire the only ones receiving particular attention, the hills n minded failed of passage; although undoubtedly some of the proposed Ini . ition would have become law. if it bad not l>een for the work of a - which was particularly opposed to one hill, calling for the annual appol ment and accounting of dividends and to another hill opposed to special or contracts. Et is interesting to note that the majority of the hills which were recomn* -ion were recommended and have since Ix-come Laws in si\ or of the I'nion. I Although there is much needed Insurance Legislation in our State, in the est of public policy and for the protection of |>olicy holder*, two rn< ting insurance should he passed at the coming session of the legislature »> should l«' a Law prohibiting the sale of s|K>cial or board contracts bj ranee Companies. Also a Law prohibiting misrepresentation by 1 classes of Companies. I There is no ciuestion hut the insurance code of Nebraska is very incomplete defective. The revision of the entire code by a competent committee anted for that purpose l>eing a pressing need. Most of the InsHi ie state are the patch work of many different legislatures. 'The majority e Laws t>eing gotten up hy or for sjiecial interests. when 1 the welfare in ■ests of the puhlic have not been consulted. ■ he following are a few illustrations of the inconsistencies and weaknea* of isurance code: The Law which is made to apply to old Line Life anies having a capital stock, is found in a few sections in Chapter Hi of the This law was originally intended for and referred to Fire Insui •National Mutual Fire Insurance Company of Omaha and the Nehraaka Mercantile Mutual Insurance Company of Lincoln not included in the Mutual FIRE • 1906 -ka Stock Companies $1!»7 Stock CampaniM (other States 842,236 Mutual Companies :U4.:i4<i i •301,519 Total 11,353,849 LIFE, ACCIDENT & MISCELLANEOUS. tl006 ska Legal Reserve Life Col TH.liUI Rcmtvc Life Cos. (other States i s:i<).i)ti_' il Benefit Life & Acciileut -nal Beneficiary Societies 1.531,148 il Hail and Plate (lias- Co- l.">..'><is ly. Casualty anil Surety Co- 143,530 ': Total •2,982,777 M,J<

Companies, so we find in the annual statement required from foreign (On,: the question — "(live the greatest aiiKnint insured by any one risk", also greatest an insured in any one block." A (xrular omission - same Law is that it is absolutely silent a- to the amount of capital required Hie Insurance code should more clearly define the authority and power of the one in charge of the Insurance Department, especially relative to ag< Companies, the right of revocation of a license should certainly be given to the Department. The Laws governing Mutual Kire Insurance Companies need a thorough re- I'nder the Mutual Benefit Law and the Law governing assessment Accident Companies, the proper protection and security is not given to safeguard the interests of policy holdi •• The Fraternal Beneficiary Law although better than that of many states is weak particularly in the matter of not requiring adequate rates before such Societies can do business in tl The present Mutual Hail Insurance Law should Ix' repealed. To place Insurance then on a safe and sound basis in this State requires an entire revision of the Insurance Code, which should l>e the careful work of a S mission composed of men of ability, some of whom should have a practical vledge of the business and who can devote more time to the subject than be spent !■ days of a legislative session. K'he COMMITTKK OK FIFTEEN was appointed at a conference of gover - attorneys general and Insurance Commissioners representing many states, n Chicago in February 1906, to frame uniform laws for the regulation of ince: Nebraska being represented on the Committee. Respectfully submitted. JOHN I. PIKKCK.
